Authors: Andre Angelo Medeiros Gomes, Olinto Liparini Pereira
Title:
Brazilian Muscodor species endophytic from coffee and
carqueja plants with potential to biological control by emission of
volatile antifungal compounds
Journal:
Antonie van Leeuwenhoek International Journal of General
and Molecular Microbiology
Keywords:
cyclosativene, fungal volatiles, phylogeny, Muscodor
coffeanum
Abstract:
Muscodor species have been reported to emit volatile
compounds with antimicrobial properties with broad spectrum against
human and plant pathogens. The aim of this study was to prospect the
Muscodor species producing antimicrobial volatiles, in tropical plants
used in alternative medicine and coffee plants in Brazil. Eleven fungal
isolates producing volatile metabolites was obtained and molecular
phylogeny revealed the presence of at least three distinct species, M.
coffeanum, M. yucatanensis and Muscodor sp. SPME/GC/MS analyses of the
mixture of volatiles emitted by Muscodor species obtained in this study
revealed the volatile profile and the presence of Cyclosativene as
compound with the highest percentage of peak per area to all isolates of
Muscodor analyzed. All Muscodor isolates tested had some effect on the
growth of Aspergillus species. Fifty-eight percent of the target species
of Aspergillus died after six days exposure to volatiles emitted by M.
coffeanum CDA 741, in addition to the inhibition of growth in A.
ochraceus inoculated into coffee beans. A discovery of new Muscodor
isolates, especially in different ecological niches with high activity
of antagonism, is a promising source of biological control agent adapted
to a particular environment that could be used on a specific site.
